title: De Blasio may quit presidential race if he doesn't make October debate
text:
Presidential candidate Bill De Blasio said he’s still holding out hope for a viral moment to lift his campaign out of the doldrums. | AP Photo/Jason DeCrow De Blasio may quit presidential race if he doesn't make October debate

Mayor Bill de Blasio said he may drop out of the 2020 presidential race if he fails to qualify for October’s Democratic debate.

“I’m going to go and try to get into the October debates, and if I can, I think that’s a good reason to keep going forward. And if I can’t, I think it’s really tough to conceive of continuing,” de Blasio told reporters Wednesday. “That’s the way I’m looking at it right now.”

Story Continued Below

De Blasio has forged ahead with his campaign for the Democratic nomination despite failing to top 1 percent in most polls, and getting shut out of the third round of debates scheduled for next week. Wednesday's comments were the first time he suggested an end date for a campaign that has struggled to capture attention nationally and continues to be a source of criticism back home.

A fourth debate, set for mid-October, will have the same requirements to qualify as the September debate: candidates must reach 2 percent in four-DNC approved polls and receive donations from 130,000 unique donors. Another New York politician, Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, exited the primary stage last week after failing to qualify for the upcoming debate.

“Of course it was disappointing not to get into September,” de Blasio said Wednesday. “But I fully gathered that October was the same standards, but with a month more to achieve them.”

Candidates have until Oct. 1 to qualify for that debate.

De Blasio said he’s still holding out hope for a viral moment to lift his campaign out of the doldrums.

“People go from unheard of to totally famous in 72 hours in America now,” he said. “So a candidate like me, who's not that well known yet — you know, ask me in 72 hours, right? Something might change.”

poster="https://static.politico.com/49/a8/0bc6edd34fc585a9f2e93ebb2ebf/artboard-1.png"

In his quest to amass small donors who would help him qualify for the debates, de Blasio has become ensnared in a feud within Brooklyn’s Orthodox Jewish community, POLITICO reported last week.

Emails and fliers circulated encouraging donations to de Blasio, and claiming the mayor promised to facilitate construction of a hotly-disputed synagogue project in return. But one sect within the feuding Satmar community said that those documents were forged to embarrass the other sect.

De Blasio said Wednesday he did not make any such promises and had no knowledge of the synagogue project until he read the POLITICO story.

“I was not aware of the issue to begin with,” he said. “If someone did forge that, that’s thoroughly disgusting and unacceptable. No, none of that ever came to my attention. And I would never make a decision on anything but the merits anyway.”

The two sides within the Williamsburg Orthodox community have been sparring over the property for the past decade, and emails produced through a freedom of information request show high-ranking city officials have been made aware of the issue.

Sally Goldenberg contributed to this report.
description: De Blasio has forged ahead with his campaign for the Democratic nomination despite failing to top 1 percent in most polls.
